metadata.name: Steam Engine Feasibility
metadata.description: Multi-level hypergraph showing how physical principles justify steam-powered engines

claims.text: Water can be heated to 100°C using available heat sources
claims.reasoning: Fire, coal, wood can easily reach temperatures >100°C
Phase transition at boiling point - well-established thermodynamics
Ideal gas law: PV = nRT - temperature increase causes expansion

claims.text: Expanding gas in a confined space creates pressure
claims.reasoning: Gas law: if volume is constrained, pressure increases with temperature

claims.text: Pressure on a surface creates force (F = P × A)
claims.reasoning: Basic mechanics: Force equals pressure times area

claims.text: Force can move objects and do mechanical work
claims.reasoning: Newton's laws: F = ma, Work = F × d

claims.text: Linear motion can be converted to rotational motion
claims.reasoning: Crankshaft mechanism - used in many machines

claims.text: Materials exist that can withstand steam pressure and temperature
claims.reasoning: Metals like iron, steel, brass can handle 100-200°C and several atmospheres. Historical evidence: steam engines were built in 1700s

claims.text: Seals and valves can contain and control pressurized steam
claims.reasoning: Various seal materials (leather, rubber, metal-on-metal) can contain steam. May have some leakage but functional

claims.text: Steam can be reliably produced from water
Steam pressure can produce controlled mechanical motion
claims.reasoning: Combining steam production, pressure generation, and mechanical work

claims.text: A steam-powered engine is physically feasible and can be constructed
claims.reasoning: All necessary physical principles are sound, materials exist, and engineering is tractable. Slight deduction for practical challenges in seals/efficiency

implications.reasoning: If we can heat water to 100°C, and water at 100°C produces steam, then we can reliably produce steam
If steam expands when heated, and expanding gas creates pressure, then confined steam creates usable pressure
If pressure creates force, and force can do work, then pressure can perform mechanical work
Combining steam production, pressure generation, and mechanical work capability gives us controlled mechanical motion from steam
If steam can produce mechanical motion, and we can convert that to rotation, and materials/seals exist, then a steam engine is feasible
